Chapter.Section: General aims of &Wedderga; package The title ``&Wedderga;'' stands for ``Wedderburn decomposition of a group algebras. This is a &GAP; package to compute the simple components of the Wedderburn decomposition of group algebras of finite groups over fields of characteristic zero and over finite fields. It also contains functions that produce the primitive central idempotents of group algebras of finite groups over the field of rationals and and over finite fields.

Main functions of &Wedderga; package
The main functions of &Wedderga; are and .
In the case when the input FG is a group algebra of a finite group G over a field F of characteristic zero,
computes a list of simple algebras such that their direct product is isomorphic to the group algebra FG, thus, the output is the complete Wedderburn decomposition of FG.
In the case when the input FG is a group algebra of a finite group G over a field F of characteristic q coprime with the order of G, computes a list of simple algebras such that their direct product is isomorphic to certain direct factor of the group algebra FG (if this is a proper direct factor, a warning will be displayed). If the group G satisfies some additional conditions, the direct product of simple algebras from the output will be isomorphic to the whole group algebra FG, so in this case the output is the complete Wedderburn decomposition of FG. For example, this is the case if G is abelian by supersolvable. (see Chapter for theoretical background).
When F is a field of characteristic zero, the entries of the output are given as matrix algebras over some crossed products over certain cyclotomic extensions of the field F. These crossed products are in fact cyclotomic algebras (see ), thus, the entries of the output of
are realizations of the Wedderburn components of FG as algebras similar to cyclotomic algebras. Recall that the Brauer-Witt Theorem ensures that every simple factor of a semisimple group ring FG is similar (that is represents the same class in the Brauer group of its centre) to a cyclotomic algebra (, ).
When F is a finite field, the simple factors of FG are also matrix algebras over division rings which are finite extensions of the field F. If F is finite then by the Wedderburn theorem these division rings are finite fields. In this case the the output of
represents the factors of FG as matrix algebras over finite extensions of the field F.
gap> QG := GroupRing( Rationals, SymmetricGroup(4) ); <algebra-with-one over Rationals, with 2 generators> gap> WedderburnDecomposition( QG ); [ Rationals, Rationals, ( Rationals^[ 3, 3 ] ), ( Rationals^[ 3, 3 ] ), <crossed product over CF(3), with 2 generators and center=Rationals> ] gap> FG := GroupRing( CF(5), SymmetricGroup(4) ); <algebra-with-one over CF(5), with 2 generators> gap> WedderburnDecomposition( FG ); [ CF(5), CF(5), ( CF(5)^[ 3, 3 ] ), ( CF(5)^[ 3, 3 ] ), <crossed product over AsField( CF(5), CF(15) ), with 2 generators and center=CF(5)> ] gap> FG := GroupRing( GF(5), SymmetricGroup(4) ); <algebra-with-one over GF(5), with 2 generators> gap> WedderburnDecomposition( FG ); [ ( GF(5)^[ 1, 1 ] ), ( GF(5)^[ 1, 1 ] ), ( GF(5)^[ 2, 2 ] ), ( GF(5)^[ 3, 3 ] ), ( GF(5)^[ 3, 3 ] ) ] gap> FG := GroupRing( GF(5), SmallGroup(24,3) ); <algebra-with-one over GF(5), with 4 generators> gap> WedderburnDecomposition( FG ); [ ( GF(5)^[ 1, 1 ] ), ( GF(5^2)^[ 1, 1 ] ), ( GF(5)^[ 2, 2 ] ), ( GF(5^2)^[ 2, 2 ] ), ( GF(5)^[ 3, 3 ] ) ]
Instead of , that returns a list of &GAP; objects, returns the numerical description of these objects. See Chapter for theoretical background.

Installation and system requirements
&Wedderga; does not use external binaries and, therefore, works without restrictions on the type of the operation system. It is designed for &GAP;4.4 and no compatibility with previous releases of &GAP;4 is guaranteed.
To use the &Wedderga; online help it is necessary to install the &GAP;4 package &GAPDoc; by Frank L\"ubeck and Max Neunh\"offer, which is available from the &GAP; site or from http://www.math.rwth-aachen.de/~Frank.Luebeck/GAPDoc/.
&Wedderga; is distributed in standard formats (zoo, tar.gz, tar.bz2, -win.zip) and can be obtained from http://ukrgap.exponenta.ru/wedderga.htm. To unpack the archive wedderga-4.0.zoo you need the program unzoo, which can be obtained from the &GAP; homepage http://www.gap-system.org/ (see section `Distribution'). To install &Wedderga;, copy this archive into the pkg subdirectory of your &GAP;4.4 installation. The subdirectory wedderga will be created in the pkg directory after the following command:
unzoo -x wedderga-4.0.zoo
